results.title: Be careful boys
results.creator_credit: Keith Learner, Nancy Hanna, Vera Linnecar, Oliver Lawson Dick and Biographic Cartoon Films
results.brief_description: Charlie Burke is a wilfully careless handler of fruit, and is generally unpopular with his fellow workers, the foreman, the producers, the fruiterers and the housewives. A visit to a psychoanalyst reforms him. He acquires a conscience and becomes a model handler, self respecting and respected.

results.title: Be a sport
results.creator_credit: Frank Gardner and Great Britain Central Office of Information
results.brief_description: A survey of sport and athletics in Great Britain, showing several champions and promising newcomers training as well as competing. Johnny Haynes demonstrates the art of ball control; Diane Leather, first women five-minute miler; Gordon Pirie competing in a two-mile event; Christine Truman, tennis star; Pat Smythe shows skill in show jumping; Jeanette Altwegge and Cecilia Colledge, figure skaters. Sporting activities play an important part in the everyday life of English people and a high degree of skill is maintained.

results.title: B.B.C. television: the first 25 years
results.brief_description: Describes Britain’s pioneering efforts with this medium, showing how the demands of war accelerated technical development and how the post-war years nursed the nation-wide impact of this home entertainment. The opening of the first regular television service from Alexandra Palace, London, in 1936; highlights from popular programmes and the linking of the BBC service with Eurovision and Intervision 25 years later. A record of successful transmission from Britain to Australia indicates a path of future achievement.

results.title: The Bayeux Tapestry
results.creator_credit: Jean-Pierre Vivet, Roger Leenhardt and Films du Compas
results.brief_description: Follows closely the narrative sequences of the Bayeux Tapestry which is, more accurately, an embroidery - a piece of coarse linen 230 feet long and 20 inches wide. The story of Harold’s journey to the continent in 1064, his experiences in Europe, the battle of 1066 and finally his death. Its origin is uncertain but the consensus of expert opinion is that it is contemporary and was probably executed in England at the order of Bishop Odo of Bayeux, William the conquerors’ half-brother, as an ornament for his then new cathedral.

results.title: A Bay in the balance
results.brief_description: In 1972, the Victorian Government responded to a conservation campaign and further industrial development in Westernport was halted. A major scientific study was initiated to examine how the relatively undeveloped bay functions and what future plans should be.

results.title: Batu caves
results.brief_description: A group of school children explores Batu Caves in Kuala Lumpur and discover interesting examples of Malayan wild life. Many varieties of bats are the chief inhabitants, while various insects, snails, crickets, centipedes, scorpions, white snakes and small crustaceans are also to be found. No other credits available.

results.title: Battle prelude
results.brief_description: With commentary by Wilfred Thomas, this is a record of the Australian Army Jungle-Training School at Canungra in Queensland during World War II. No other credits available.

results.title: The Battle of Wangapore
results.brief_description: In this satirical animation British troops under a typical Colonel Blimp test the turbanned and rebellious riff-raff from over the border and all with a stiff sense of propriety. The story tracks back to the good old days on the North West Frontier of India. An example of animation technique as used by an amateur production group. Animation by Richard Horn and Ken Clark. (See also Title Code 006110 “Let battle begin” for the history of the making of the cartoon.)

results.title: Battle for the Bulge
results.brief_description: Uses location filming and historical footage to document the ‘Battle for the Bulge’, the last big German offensive in World War II. Portrays the heroism, as well as the confusion and humiliation, that characterised both the Allied and German troops.

results.title: Batman's village
results.creator_credit: Ivor P. Kershaw and Factual Films of Australia
results.brief_description: A picturesque view of Melbourne city interspersed with factual information on its history and the key figures involved in its establishment. Inner city streets, buildings and botanical gardens are shown.
